net.hudup.core.parser

Class TextParserUtil

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.hudup.core.parser.TextParserUtil

  • public final class TextParserUtil
extends java.lang.Object
    This final utility class provides constants and static methods for parsing, converting, encrypting, decrypting, splitting a text. This class is used more by classes that implement TextParsable interface. In the future, this utility class is replaced by support of JSON format. JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is a human-read format used for interchange between many protocols, available at http://www.json.org.
    Version:
    10.0
    Author:
    Loc Nguyen

    • Field Detail

      • DEFAULT_SEP

        public static final java.lang.String DEFAULT_SEP
        Default Java regular expression for splitting a sentence into many words (tokens), including space. Note that regular expression is a string pattern for editing and finding texts (words, characters) in string of texts. Please see https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/essential/regex for more details about regular expression.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • NOSPACE_DEFAULT_SEP

        public static final java.lang.String NOSPACE_DEFAULT_SEP
        Default Java regular expression for splitting a sentence into many words (tokens), including space. Note that regular expression is a string pattern for editing and finding texts (words, characters) in string of texts. Please see https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/essential/regex for more details about regular expression.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • SPEC_CHAR

        public static final java.lang.String SPEC_CHAR
        There are many special characters called reserved characters for other purposes, for example, "\\n", ",", "=", "{", "}". There is a mapping a reserved character to a special string. Such special string uses this constant to encode itself. For example, the character "\\n" is mapped to the string "xreturnx". Some static methods of this class use such mapping for their own tasks such as encryptReservedChars(String) method and decryptReservedChars(String) method.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • NULL_STRING

        public static final java.lang.String NULL_STRING
        There are many special characters called reserved characters for other purposes, for example, "\\n", ",", "=", "{", "}". There is a mapping a reserved character to a special string. This constant "xnull" is the special string of null character.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • NEW_LINE

        public static final java.lang.String NEW_LINE
        There are many special characters called reserved characters for other purposes, for example, "\\n", ",", "=", "{", "}". There is a mapping a reserved character to a special string. This constant "xnline" is the special string of new line character.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • MAIN_SEP

        public static final java.lang.String MAIN_SEP
        Main separating character to split a string into many words (tokens). This character is a reserved character, ":". For example, the string "apple:orange" is split into two words "apple" and "orange".
        See Also:

        The special string of reserved character MAIN_SEP. In current implementation, it is "xcolonx".

        The character is used to specify an extra part of a word or of a string. For example, we have string having a extra part "user_id#1".
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • EXTRA_SEP_REPLACE

        public static final java.lang.String EXTRA_SEP_REPLACE
        The special string of reserved character EXTRA_SEP. In current implementation, it is "xsharpx".
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • RESERVED_CHARS

        public static final java.lang.String[][] RESERVED_CHARS
        There are many special characters called reserved characters for other purposes, for example, "\\n", ",", "=", "{", "}". This constant makes a lookup table between every reserved character and a special string. Concretely, this constant is an array of many entries. Each entry has two elements in which the first element is a reserved character and the second element is a respective special string. Methods encryptReservedChars(String) and decryptReservedChars(String) uses this lookup table for encryption and decryption in which a reserved character is replaced by a special string (encryption) and a reserved character is recovered from a special string (decryption). In current implementation, following is the lookup table represented by this constant:
        • ":" <-> "xcolonx"
        • "~" <-> "xtildex"
        • "_" <-> "xconnx"
        • "#" <-> "xsharpx"
        • "\\n" <-> "xreturnx"
        • "," <-> "xcommax"
        • "=" <-> "xequalx"
        • "{" <-> "xopen_bracketx"
        • "}" <-> "xclose_bracketx"

    • Constructor Detail

      • TextParserUtil

        public TextParserUtil()

    • Method Detail

      • encryptReservedChars

        public static java.lang.String encryptReservedChars(java.lang.String text)
        There are many special characters called reserved characters for other purposes, for example, "\\n", ",", "=", "{", "}". This method replaces every reserved characters by a special string, for example, "\\n" is replaced by "xreturnx". Such replacement is called encryption. This method looks the constant RESERVED_CHARS for encryption.
        Parameters:
        text - Specified text may contain reserved characters.
        Returns:
        The encrypted text derived from the special text in which every reserved character is replaced by a special string.

      • encryptReservedChars

        public static java.util.List<java.lang.String> encryptReservedChars(java.util.Collection<java.lang.String> textList)
        This method applies replacements (encryptions) of reserved characters into every text element of the specified collection. In other words, this method calls encryptReservedChars(String) many times.
        Parameters:
        textList - The specified collection of texts.
        Returns:
        List of encrypted texts. In each encrypted text, every reserved character is replaced by a special string.

      • decryptReservedChars

        public static java.lang.String decryptReservedChars(java.lang.String text)
        This method is opposite to the encryptReservedChars(String) method. There are many special characters called reserved characters for other purposes, for example, "\\n", ",", "=", "{", "}". When the specified text was encrypted by replacing every reserved character a special string by calling encryptReservedChars(String) before, This method will recover all reserved characters from special strings. For example, the special string "xreturnx" is recovered as the reserved character "\\n". This method looks the constant RESERVED_CHARS for decryption.
        Parameters:
        text - the specified text was encrypted by replacing every reserved character a special string by calling encryptReservedChars(String) before.
        Returns:
        plain text is decrypted by recovering all reserved characters from special strings.

      • decryptReservedChars

        public static java.util.List<java.lang.String> decryptReservedChars(java.util.Collection<java.lang.String> textList)
        This method applies recoveries (decryptions) of reserved characters from special strings into every encrypted text element of the specified collection. In other words, this method calls decryptReservedChars(String) many times.
        Parameters:
        textList - Specified collection of encrypted texts.
        Returns:
        List of plain texts. Each plain text is decrypted by recovering all reserved characters from special strings.

      • split

        public static final java.util.List<java.lang.String> split(java.lang.String source,
                                                           java.lang.String sep,
                                                           java.lang.String remove)
        Splitting a specified string into many words (tokens). The character (string) that is used for separation is specified by the parameter sep which follows Java regular expression. For each returned word (token), the string that specified by the parameter remove is removed from such word.
        Parameters:
        source - Specified string.
        sep - The character (string) that is used for separation.
        remove - the string which is removed from each tokens.
        Returns:
        List of words (tokens) from splitting the specified string.

      • toText

        public static java.lang.String toText(java.util.BitSet bs)
        Converting a specified bit set represented by BitSet class into text form like "01101001111". Note that bit set is an array of binary elements. Essentially, any integer is specified by a bit set but the built-in BitSet class expresses an unlimited-length bit set.
        Parameters:
        bs - Specified bit set.
        Returns:
        Text form of the specified bit set.

      • parseBitSet

        public static java.util.BitSet parseBitSet(java.lang.String spec)
        Converting a specified text form like "01101001111" into a bit set represented by BitSet class. Note that bit set is an array of binary elements. Essentially, any integer is specified by a bit set but the built-in BitSet class expresses an unlimited-length bit set. This method is opposite to the toText(BitSet) method.
        Parameters:
        spec - Specified text form of a bit set.
        Returns:
        Bit set of the specified text form.

      • toText

        public static <T> java.lang.String toText(T[] array,
                                          java.lang.String sep)
        Converting a specified array of objects (any type) into a string in which each object is converted as a word in such string. Words in such returned string are connected by the character specified by the parameter sep. This is template static method and so the type of object is specified by the template <T>.
        Type Parameters:
        T - type of each object in the specified array.
        Parameters:
        array - Specified array of objects.
        sep - The character that is used to connect words in the returned string. As usual, it is a comma ",".
        Returns:
        Text form (string) of the specified array of objects, in which each object is converted as a word in such text form.

      • toText

        public static java.lang.String toText(double[] array,
                                      java.lang.String sep)
        Converting a specified array of double numbers into a string. Words in such returned string are connected by the character specified by the parameter sep.
        Parameters:
        array - Specified array of objects.
        sep - The character that is used to connect words in the returned string. As usual, it is a comma ",".
        Returns:
        Text form (string) of the specified array of double numbers.

      • toColumnText

        public static java.lang.StringBuffer toColumnText(double[] array)
        Converting a specified array of double numbers into a column list of strings. Words in such returned string are connected by the character specified by the parameter sep.
        Parameters:
        array - Specified array of objects.
        Returns:
        Column list of strings given the specified array of double numbers.

      • toColumnText

        public static java.lang.StringBuffer toColumnText(double[] array,
                                                  int decimalPrecision)
        Converting a specified array of double numbers into a column list of strings with default format. Words in such returned string are connected by the character specified by the parameter sep.
        Parameters:
        array - Specified array of objects.
        decimalPrecision - format decimal precision.
        Returns:
        Column list of strings given the specified array of double numbers.

      • toText

        public static <T> java.lang.String toText(java.util.Collection<T> list,
                                          java.lang.String sep)
        Converting a specified collection of objects (any type) into a string in which each object is converted as a word in such string. Words in such returned string are connected by the character specified by the parameter sep. This is template static method and so the type of object is specified by the template <T>.
        Type Parameters:
        T - type of each object in the specified collection.
        Parameters:
        list - Specified collection of objects.
        sep - The character that is used to connect words in the returned string. As usual, it is a comma ",".
        Returns:
        Text form (string) of the specified collection of objects, in which each object is converted as a word in such text form.

      • toColumnText

        public static <T> java.lang.StringBuffer toColumnText(java.util.Collection<T> list)
        Converting a specified collection of objects (any type) into a column string list in which each object is converted as a word in such string. Words in such returned string are connected by the character specified by the parameter sep. This is template static method and so the type of object is specified by the template <T>.
        Type Parameters:
        T - type of each object in the specified collection.
        Parameters:
        list - Specified collection of objects.
        Returns:
        Column string list of the specified collection of objects, in which each object is converted as a word in such text form.

      • parseTextList

        public static java.util.List<java.lang.String> parseTextList(java.lang.String text,
                                                             java.lang.String sep)
        Splitting (parsing) a specified string into many words (tokens). The character (string) that is used for separation is specified by the parameter sep which follows Java regular expression.
        Parameters:
        text - specified text string.
        sep - The character (string) that is used for separation.
        Returns:
        List of words (tokens) from splitting the specified string.

      • toText

        public static <K,V> java.lang.String toText(java.util.Map<K,V> map,
                                            java.lang.String sep)
        Converting a specified map of key-value pairs (entries) into a string in which each key-value pair is converted as a part in form "key=value" of such string. Parts in such returned string are connected by the character specified by the parameter sep. This is template static method and so the types of key and value is specified by template <K> and template <V>, respectively.
        Type Parameters:
        K - type of key.
        V - type of value.
        Parameters:
        map - specified map of key-value pairs (entries).
        sep - character that is used to connect parts in the returned string. As usual, it is a comma ",".
        Returns:
        string of the specified map of entries, in which each entry is converted as a part in form "key=value" of such string. An example of this returned string is "key1=value1,key2=value2,key3=value3"

      • parseTextMap

        public static java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> parseTextMap(java.lang.String text,
                                                                            java.lang.String sep)
        Parsing (splitting) a specified string into many entries of the returned map. The character (string) that is used for separation is specified by the parameter sep which follows Java regular expression. Each entry is a pair of key and value. So the original specified string has a form "key1=value1,key2=value2,key3=value3". This method is opposite to toText(Map, String) method.
        Parameters:
        text - specified text string.
        sep - character (string) that is used for separation.
        Returns:
        Map of entries which are key-value pairs, parsed from the specified string.

      • toText

        public static <K,V extends TextParsable> void toText(java.util.Map<K,V> map,
                                                     java.io.Writer writer)
        Writing a specified map of key-value pairs (entries) via Writer in which each key-value pair is converted as a part in form "key=value". These parts are connected by the character specified by the parameter sep. This is template static method and so the types of key and value is specified by template <K> and template <V>, respectively.
        Type Parameters:
        K - type of key.
        V - type of value.
        Parameters:
        map - specified map of key-value pairs (entries).
        writer - Writer for writing the specified map of key-value pairs (entries).

      • parseTextParsableMap

        public static <K,V extends TextParsable> java.util.Map<K,V> parseTextParsableMap(java.io.Reader reader,
                                                                                 java.lang.Class<K> k,
                                                                                 java.lang.Class<V> v)
        Parsing from an archive (file) by Reader line by line and then conversing such lines into many entries of the returned map. Each entry is a pair of key and value. So each line read by Reader has a form "key1=value1,key2=value2,key3=value3".
        Type Parameters:
        K - type of key.
        V - type of value.
        Parameters:
        reader - Reader for reading an archive (file) line by line.
        k - class of key.
        v - class of value.
        Returns:
        Map of entries which are key-value pairs.

      • parseTextParsableList

        public static <T extends TextParsable> java.util.List<T> parseTextParsableList(java.lang.String string,
                                                                               java.lang.Class<T> classType,
                                                                               java.lang.String sep)
        Splitting and parsing a specified string into many objects. The character (string) that is used for separation is specified by the parameter sep which follows Java regular expression. A returned objects must implement TextParsable directly or indirectly, called text parsable objects.
        Type Parameters:
        T - type of returned objects, which must implement TextParsable directly or indirectly.
        Parameters:
        string - specified string.
        classType - class of returned objects, which plays the role of template for parsing. This class must be the class of text-parsable object.
        sep - character (string) that is used for separation.
        Returns:
        List of text-parsable objects parsed from specified string.

      • parseListByClass

        public static <T> java.util.List<T> parseListByClass(java.lang.String string,
                                                     java.lang.Class<T> type,
                                                     java.lang.String sep)
        Splitting and parsing a specified string into many objects. The character (string) that is used for separation is specified by the parameter sep which follows Java regular expression. The class of returned objects are arbitrary. This method is more general that parseTextParsableList(String, Class, String) method.
        Type Parameters:
        T - type of returned objects.
        Parameters:
        string - specified string.
        type - class of returned objects, which plays the role of template for parsing.
        sep - character (string) that is used for separation.
        Returns:
        List of objects parsed from specified string.

      • parseObjectByClass

        public static java.lang.Object parseObjectByClass(java.lang.String string,
                                                  java.lang.Class<?> type)
        Parsing (converting) a specified string into an object according to a class.
        Parameters:
        string - specified string.
        type - class of the parsed object.
        Returns:
        parsed object.

      • parseObjectByClass

        public static java.lang.Object parseObjectByClass(java.lang.String string,
                                                  java.lang.String className)
        Parsing (converting) a specified string into an object according to a full name of the specified class. An example of the full name of a class is "net.hudup.core.parser.TextParsable".
        Parameters:
        string - specified string.
        className - full name of the specified class.
        Returns:
        object parsed from the specified string.
